revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Use Australian English|date=September 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox MP | honorific-prefix = [[The Honourable]] | name = Sir Thomas White | honorific-suffix = {{post-nominals|country=AUS|size=100%|sep=,|KBE|DFC}} | image = File:Thomas Walter White 1930.jpg | image_alt = Formal head-and-shoulders portrait of Thomas White in suit and tie | caption = Thomas White, Melbourne, c. 1930 | constituency_MP = [[Division of Balaclava|Balaclava]] | parliament = Australian | majority = | predecessor = [[William Watt (Australian politician)|William Watt]] | successor = [[Percy Joske]] | term_start = 3 August 1929 | term_end = 21 June 1951 | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1888|4|26}} | birth_place = [[North Melbourne, Victoria]] | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1957|10|13|1888|4|26}} | death_place = [[South Yarra, Victoria]] | nationality = Australian | spouse = Vera Deakin | party = [[Nationalist Party of Australia|Nationalist]] (1929–31)
[[United Australia Party|United Australia]] (1931–45)
[[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal]] (1945–51) | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = Soldier; company director | profession = | religion = | signature = | website = | footnotes = |servicenumber = | allegiance = Australia | branch = [[Australian Flying Corps]] (1914–20)
{{nowrap|[[Royal Australian Air Force]] (1940–44)}} |serviceyears = 1911–44 |rank = [[Group Captain]] |unit = [[Mesopotamian Half Flight]] (1915) |commands = [[6th Battalion (Australia)|6th Battalion]] (1926–31) |battles = First World War * [[Mesopotamian campaign]] Second World War * [[European theatre of World War II|European theatre]] | mawards = [[Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire]]
[[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]]
[[Mentioned in Despatches]] (2) }} '''Sir Thomas Walter White''', {{post-nominals|country=AUS|size=100%|sep=,|KBE|DFC}} (26 April 1888 – 13 October 1957) was an Australian politician and First World War pilot. He was one of the first airmen trained for the [[Australian Flying Corps]] in 1914, and among the first to see action when he deployed to the Middle East with the [[Mesopotamian Half Flight]] in 1915. He was captured in November that year but escaped in July 1918. Awarded the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] and twice [[mentioned in despatches]], White began his parliamentary career in 1929 when he was elected [[Division of Balaclava|Member for Balaclava]] in [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]. He served as [[Minister for Trade and Investment (Australia)|Minister for Trade and Customs]] in [[Joseph Lyons]]' [[United Australia Party]] government from 1932 to 1938, but resigned when he was excluded from Lyons' inner [[Cabinet of Australia|cabinet]]. He joined the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) during the Second World War and saw service in Australia and the United Kingdom. Returning to parliament as a member of the newly formed [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal Party]] in 1945, he served as [[Minister for Air (Australia)|Minister for Air]] and [[Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government (Australia)|Minister for Civil Aviation]] in [[Robert Menzies]]' government from 1949 to 1951. His term coincided with the commitment of RAAF squadrons to the [[Korean War]] and the [[Malayan Emergency]]. Australia's [[List of High Commissioners of Australia to the United Kingdom|High Commissioner to the United Kingdom]] from 1951 to 1956, White was [[Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire|knighted]] in 1952 and died in October 1957. ==Early life and First World War== Thomas Walter White was born on 26 April 1888 at Hotham, [[North Melbourne, Victoria|North Melbourne]], the son of Charles James White, a [[brass]]-finisher from England, and Emily Jane Jenkins of Victoria. Educated at Moreland State School, White was commissioned in the [[5th Australian Regiment]], [[Citizen Military Forces]] (CMF), in 1911.{{Australian Dictionary of Biography|last=Rickard |first=John |authorlink= |year=2002|id=A160636b|title= White, Sir Thomas Walter (1888–1957) |accessdate=18 January 2016}} In August 1914, two weeks after the outbreak of the First World War, he became one of the first four students to commence training at [[RAAF Williams|Point Cook]] as a pilot in the [[Australian Flying Corps]] (AFC).Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 3–4 He was later described by a biographer as "pugnacious and impatient for success, with a disdain for authority and a suspicion of elites".Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', p. 7 White recalled flying in the school's [[Bristol Boxkite]] thus: "The senses took the place of the instruments. One's eyes and ears did duty as engine counters; the rush of the air in the face told whether the climb or glide was at the right angle."Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', p. 8 He graduated with his four fellow students, who included future [[Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Chief of the Air Staff]] (Sir) [[Richard Williams (RAAF officer)|Richard Williams]], in November.Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', p. 10 [[File:A02253Petre1915.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.28|Captain White (second left) with Captain [[Henry Petre]] (far left) and Lieutenant George Merz (far right) of the Mesopotamian Half Flight at Basra, July 1915|alt=Four men in khaki military uniforms, two wearing pith helmets (one of whom has his arm in a sling), seated in front of a boy]] In April 1915, White was appointed a [[Captain (British Army and Royal Marines)|captain]] in the [[First Australian Imperial Force|Australian Imperial Force]] and [[adjutant]] of the [[Mesopotamian Half Flight]], the first AFC unit to see active service.Cutlack, [https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1069785--1-.pdf ''The Australian Flying Corps'', pp. 1–3] Based initially in [[Basra]] and operating primitive [[Maurice Farman]] biplanes, the Half Flight assisted the [[British Indian Army|Indian Army]] during the [[Mesopotamian campaign]], conducting [[reconnaissance]] and [[sabotage]] missions.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 5–6 White successfully carried out several operations that involved landing behind enemy lines. On a mission in October 1915, he was forced to land owing to engine trouble and, rather than risk attempting repairs, [[taxiing|taxied]] the aircraft some {{convert|24|km|mi|spell=on}} past enemy encampments while his observer kept watch with his rifle at the ready; the "[[Keystone Cops]] adventure", as historian Alan Stephens described it, culminated in the engine finally powering up and allowing White to take off and fly to the safety of the Australian base.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 7 White himself touted the feat as "a taxi-ing record".Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', p. 19 On 13 November 1915, White was captured while attempting to cut telegraph wires near [[Baghdad]]. He was [[mentioned in despatches]] in July 1916.{{LondonGazette|issue=29665 |supp=yes|startpage=6959|endpage=6960|date=13 July 1916|accessdate=18 January 2016}} Imprisoned in Turkey, he escaped from a train in [[Constantinople]] in July 1918 and managed to stow away on a cargo ship to [[Odessa]], Ukraine, before travelling to London. His experience of the [[Soviet]]s in Odessa helped inform his subsequent [[anti-communism]]. White was awarded the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] in June 1919.{{LondonGazette|issue=31378 |supp=yes|startpage=7031|endpage=7032|date=3 June 1919|accessdate=18 January 2016}} In December, he was again mentioned in despatches, for "valuable services whilst in captivity".{{LondonGazette|issue=31691 |supp=yes|startpage=15613|endpage=15614|date=16 December 1919|accessdate=18 January 2016}} Still in London, he met Vera Deakin, daughter of former Australian Prime Minister [[Alfred Deakin]], and promptly became engaged to her. White was discharged from the AIF in January 1920, and married Vera on 22 March at St John's Church of England in [[Toorak, Victoria|Toorak]], despite the opposition of some of the Deakin family. That year he also became managing director of his father's hardware company, C.J. White & Sons Pty Ltd. From 1926 to 1931, he commanded the [[6th Battalion (Australia)|6th Battalion]], CMF, as a [[lieutenant colonel]]. In 1928 he published an account of his wartime exploits as ''Guests of the Unspeakable''.{{cite book| last =White | first =Thomas Walter| title =Guests of the Unspeakable: The Odyssey of an Australian Airman – Being a Record of Captivity and Escape in Turkey | publisher =John Hamilton| year =1928| location =London | isbn = 1-86315-000-5 }} ==Parliamentary career and Second World War== White ran unsuccessfully as a [[Nationalist Party of Australia|Nationalist]] for the [[Australian House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] seat of [[Division of Maribyrnong|Maribyrnong]] in the [[Australian federal election, 1925|1925 elections]]. In 1927, he failed to win the [[Victorian Legislative Assembly]] seat of [[Electoral district of Prahran|Prahran]]. Denied pre-selection as a Nationalist for the [[Australian Senate|Senate]] the following year, he won the seat of [[Division of Balaclava|Balaclava]] at a [[Balaclava by-election, 1929|by-election]] held on 3 August 1929. He succeeded retiring member [[William Watt (Australian politician)|William Watt]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article51613541 |title=Federal Parliament |newspaper=[[The Examiner (Tasmania)|The Examiner]] |location=Launceston |date=15 August 1929 |accessdate=20 January 2016 |page=7 |publisher=[[National Library of Australia]]}} The [[United Australia Party]] (UAP) came to power in the [[Australian federal election, 1931|1931 elections]] and in March 1933 he was appointed [[Minister for Trade and Investment (Australia)|Minister for Trade and Customs]] in the [[first Lyons Ministry]], replacing [[Henry Gullett]], who had stood down due to ill-health.{{Australian Dictionary of Biography|last=Hill |first=A.J. |year=1983|id=A090132b|title= Gullett, Sir Henry Somer (1878–1940) |accessdate=18 January 2016 }} White had given up the directorship of C.J. White & Sons the previous year. His portfolio was responsible for reducing [[tariff]]s and attempting to increase trade with Britain as opposed to the United States and Japan, and also with book and film censorship; for the latter he established an advisory board, chaired by [[Robert Garran]], to make recommendations to him. In 1934, White became Australian chairman of the [[Royal Life Saving Society]], serving until 1951; he was also an active supporter of such organisations as [[Legacy Australia|Legacy]] and the [[Royal Flying Doctor Service of Australia|Royal Flying Doctor Service]]. [[File:Thomas Walter White 1942 (AWM 011735).JPG|thumb|right|Wing Commander White (right) serving with the RAAF in Great Britain, March 1942|alt=Informal head-and-shoulders portrait of Thomas Walter White in and unidentified man in background, both wearing air force uniforms with peaked caps]] In July 1938, White represented Australia at an [[Évian Conference|inter-governmental conference on Jewish refugees]] held at [[Évian-les-Bains|Évian]], France, to discuss the growing numbers of Jewish emigrants seeking to leave Germany and occupied territories. He expressed remorse after listening to stories from refugees during the conference, but ultimately hedged his offer of support, saying that, "As we have no real racial problem, we are not desirous of importing one by encouraging any scheme of large-scale foreign migration".{{cite web|title=The Fateful Year |url=http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/holocaust/about/01/crucial_year.asp|publisher=[[Yad Vashem]]|accessdate=18 January 2016}} Australia would go on to accept 15,000 refugees over three years.Sykes, ''Cross Roads to Israel'', pp. 198–199 White's reaction to the Australian government's support for the [[Munich Agreement]] was to diarise: "I think we should hang our heads that we did not stand up to the bully of Europe ... It may yet mean peace but at what price?"Martin, ''Robert Menzies: A Life – Volume I'', p. 237 He called for stronger preparations at home in case of war, including the introduction of [[conscription]].Henderson, ''Joseph Lyons'', p. 412 On 8 November 1938, he resigned his portfolio, having discovered that [[Joseph Lyons]] had established an inner [[Cabinet of Australia|cabinet]] from which he was excluded. Lyons' response in parliament to White's resignation publicly highlighted the divisions in the UAP.Henderson, ''Joseph Lyons'', p. 419 White stood for the UAP's leadership after Lyons' death the following year but was eliminated early in the balloting, and [[Robert Menzies]] eventually became leader. With the outbreak of the Second World War, White became a [[flight lieutenant]] (temporary [[squadron leader]]) in the part-time [[Citizen Air Force]]. He took leave from parliament in April 1940 and was appointed the inaugural commanding officer of No. 1 Initial Training School at [[Somers, Victoria|Somers]], Victoria.Gillison, [https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070724--1-.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 97] The following year he travelled to England, where he administered Australian airmen at [[Bournemouth]], served as [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) Liaison Officer with [[RAF Training Command]], and commanded [[Brighton|RAF Station Brighton]].Gillison, [https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070475--1-.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 35] According to the Parliamentary Library of Australia, White also "surreptitiously flew on several [[sortie]]s as a [[co-pilot|second-pilot]]".{{cite report|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/binaries/library/pubs/rb/2006-07/07rb10.pdf |author=Parliamentary Library|date=26 March 2007|title=Commonwealth Members of Parliament who have served in war|pages=9–10|accessdate=31 January 2016}} He paid tribute to the men of the [[British Commonwealth Air Training Plan|Empire Air Training Scheme]] with the narrative poem ''Sky Saga'' in 1943. Returning to [[Melbourne]] later that year, White served at [[RAAF Staff College|RAAF Staff School]] until his discharge as an honorary [[group captain]] in October 1944.{{cite web|url=http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/Veteran.aspx?serviceId=R&veteranId=1067609|title=White, Thomas Walter|work=World War 2 Nominal Roll|accessdate=18 January 2016}} The same month, he attended the conference that resulted in the establishment of the [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal Party]]; the new party was officially launched in August 1945.{{cite web|author= Ian Hancock|title= The Origins of the Modern Liberal Party |publisher= National Library of Australia |work= Harold White Fellowships |url=http://www.nla.gov.au/grants/haroldwhite/papers/ihancock.html |accessdate=20 January 2016}} Following the election of the Menzies Liberal government in the [[Australian federal election, 1949|1949 elections]], White was appointed [[Minister for Air (Australia)|Minister for Air]] and [[Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government (Australia)|Minister for Civil Aviation]], despite his personal animosity for Menzies, which partly stemmed from the latter's failure to serve in the First World War.Martin, ''Robert Menzies: A Life – Volume II'', pp. 129–130 In January 1950, White and the [[Minister for Defence (Australia)|Minister for Supply and Development]], [[Richard Casey, Baron Casey|Richard Casey]], announced that the [[English Electric Canberra]] had been selected to replace the RAAF's [[Avro Lincoln]] bombers and that the new jet would be manufactured by the [[Government Aircraft Factories|Government Aircraft Factory]] in Victoria.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18140434 |title=Speedy plane |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=Sydney |date=13 January 1950 |accessdate=20 January 2016 |page=1 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} White's term as Minister for Air saw the deployment of RAAF squadrons to the [[Korean War]] and the [[Malayan Emergency]] in mid-1950, and the establishment of the [[Women's Royal Australian Air Force]], the successor organisation to the wartime [[Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force]], that November.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article124616531 |title=1950 a fine year for RAAF |newspaper=[[The Queensland Times]] |location=Ipswich |date=8 January 1951 |accessdate=22 January 2016 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 205, 209, 244 The following year he gave his approval for the manufacture of a [[CAC Sabre|licensed version]] of the [[North American F-86 Sabre]] jet fighter for the RAAF, and played a major part in the controversial decision to replace the long-serving Chief of the Air Staff, Air Marshal (Sir) [[George Jones (RAAF officer)|George Jones]], with an RAF officer, Air Vice Marshal (later [[Air Chief Marshal]] Sir) [[Donald Hardman]].Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 73, 347Helson, ''The Private Air Marshal'', pp. 348–352 White also sought to strengthen the Citizen Air Force, and personally ordered the establishment of [[No. 24 Squadron RAAF|No. 24 (City of Adelaide) Squadron]] at [[RAAF Base Mallala|Mallala]], South Australia.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 326 ==Later life== On 21 June 1951, White resigned from parliament to become [[List of High Commissioners of Australia to the United Kingdom|Australian High Commissioner to the United Kingdom]], a position he held until 1956. He was succeeded as the member for Balaclava by Liberal [[Percy Joske]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article99522939 |title=20th Parliament to meet for last session on April 6 |newspaper=The Examiner |location=Launceston |date=24 March 1954 |accessdate=20 January 2016 |page=19 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} White was appointed a [[Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] in January 1952.{{LondonGazette|issue=39422 |supp=yes|startpage=38|date=1 January 1952|accessdate=18 January 2016}} As High Commissioner he advocated continued British migration to Australia and participated in the renewal of the [[Ten Pound Pom|assisted passage scheme]] between the two countries in 1954.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article69966194 |title=Immigration pact with UK renewed |newspaper=[[The Advocate (Australia)|The Advocate]] |location=Burnie, Tasmania |date=2 April 1954 |accessdate=24 January 2016 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27226847 |title=Migrants needed |newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart |date=16 August 1954 |accessdate=24 January 2016 |page=10 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} He suffered from [[emphysema]] and on 13 October 1957 died of a heart attack at his home in the Melbourne suburb of [[South Yarra, Victoria|South Yarra]]. Survived by his wife and four daughters, he was accorded a [[state funeral]] at [[St Paul's Cathedral, Melbourne]], and interred at [[Point Lonsdale]] cemetery.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article91240189 |title=Memorial service to Sir Thomas White |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |location=Canberra |date=17 October 1957 |accessdate=20 January 2016 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} His daughters donated his papers to the [[National Library of Australia]] in 1997 and 1998.{{cite web|url=http://www.nla.gov.au/ms/findaids/9148.html#bio|title=Papers of Sir Thomas White (1888–1957)|location=Canberra|publisher=National Library of Australia | accessdate=8 February 2016}} ==Notes== Publishing Service]]|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Publications/Details/214/Going-Solo-The-Royal-Australian-Air-Force-19461971.aspx|isbn=0-644-42803-1}} *{{cite book|last=Stephens| first=Alan|origyear=2001|year=2006| title=The Royal Australian Air Force: A History| location=London| publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|isbn=0-19-555541-4}} *{{cite book|title = Cross Roads to Israel: Palestine from Balfour to Bevin|last = Sykes|first = Christopher|publisher = [[New English Library]]|year = 1967|isbn = |location = London|oclc=716505598}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book|last=Brenchley|first=Fred|last2=Brenchley|first2=Elizabeth |title= White's Flight: An Australian Pilot's Epic Escape From Turkish Prison Camp to Russia's Revolution|publisher= [[John Wiley & Sons]]|location= Brisbane|year= 2004|isbn=978-1-74031-100-7}} ==External links== *{{cite web |url=http://www.awm.gov.au/exhibitions/stolenyears/ww1/turkey/ |title=Stolen Years: Australian Prisoners of
